Award.AwardTitle: Causal Relationships Underlying the Collective Dynamic Behavior of Swarms

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Living in groups affords several benefits for animals such as better feeding opportunities and reduced predation risks. In both instances-foraging and predator avoidance-critical information is transmitted nonverbally throughout the group, at different time scales. While current methods in animal behavior allow for inferring information sharing during coordinated maneuvers, these interactions are only a small subset of the complex behavioral repertoire of animal groups. This award supports fundamental research to investigate directional information flow underlying collective animal behavior, through the integration of dynamical systems theory and behavioral studies on the zebra fish animal model. The implications of this research are potentially transformative in the area of behavioral brain research and neuropsychobiology, where zebra fish is rapidly emerging as a valid preclinical animal model. Complementing the research are interdisciplinary education and outreach activities that will foster outside-the-box and multidisciplinary thinking in underrepresented students in engineering, and benefit the education of underprivileged students in Brooklyn public schools.

This research program seeks to demonstrate that an information-theoretic approach can be used to measure social animal behavior. Specifically, this award will establish a rigorous model-free framework to study causal relationships in animal interactions. A series of hypothesis-driven experiments on zebra fish will be conducted to emphasize unidirectional information transfer by controlling visual feedback between conspecifics and using independently controlled robotic replicas. Subsequently, the proposed model-free framework and established experimental paradigms will be used to investigate information flow in shoaling and schooling zebra fish along with the social implications of individual differences on their collective behavior. Toward this aim, robotics-based platforms, multi-target tracking software, and novel experimental protocols will be utilized for engineering and dissecting causal relationships that are central to the validation of the envisioned approach. The unique datasets from these laboratory experiments will support the validation of a multitude of theoretical dynamical-systems approaches toward unraveling causality in complex biological and technological systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have demonstrated a data-driven, model-free approach to quantify directional information flow underlying collective animal behavior. Our approach is centered around the information-theoretic concept of transfer entropy, which can be used to identify causal relationships in coupled dynamical systems from raw time-series. From pairs of animals to large groups, we have established a mathematically-principled framework to robustly identify leaders from followers, clarify the intertwined dynamics of predators and preys, and diagnose the effect of pharmacological manipulations and morphophysiological differences on social behavior. Alongside technical advancements in information theory, network science, and dynamical systems, we have contributed a series of hypothesis-driven studies on the interactions between live zebrafish and robotic replicas, inspired by conspecifics and predators. Through these highly-controlled experiments, we were able to engineer the information flow within the group, thereby creating ground-truth datasets on which we could test the validity of our theoretical framework. Building upon these findings, we applied our framework on a wider range of experimental settings in the areas of behavioral brain research and neuropsychobiology, where zebrafish is emerging as a preclinical animal model of choice.  Former collaborations were reinforced through a subaward to Northern Illinois University. One post-doctoral fellow and several graduate and undergraduate students have received training in interdisciplinary research across diagnostics, robotics, and animal behavior, publishing their findings in international journals and presenting at technical conferences. Also, middle and high-school teachers and students have been involved in hands-on research and project-based learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Research findings have been heavily disseminated to the general public through formal learning activities and numerous informal learning events (including lab exhibitions, city-wide events at the New York aquarium, the Sci-Ed Innovators Expo, the Hudson River Park's SUBMERGE festival, the World Science Festival, the Children's STEM Activity Fair in Brooklyn, the New York University Research Expo, lectures in several public schools, and pop-up exhibits), in which participants interacted with robotic replicas and were introduced to exciting and relevant STEM concepts related to the project.
